reviewText: I like westerns and Gunsmoke series is the tops! I refuse to buy this season 10 or any season until the price comes down to about 20.00, not 42.50! If enough of us refuse to pay this crazy stupid price then it will have to come down, poor marketing whoever is behind this pricing!!!!

Just picked up an advance copy at my local Record store for $70 CDN ($60 US) , how exciting, new opening and closing credits, 31 hours of 36 digitally remastered 52 minute episodes on 10 discs, that's less than $2 US per episode. Excellent bright, clear, crisp, sharp picture image, colorful easy to navigate menus, optional subitles provided, clean professional packaging... altogether a perfect product. So Chester is out and Festus is in, and Burt Reynolds returns in his regular role as half-Comanche blacksmith Quint Asper. An episode guide is included, but here's a quick list with some of the guest stars this season.

Outstanding episodes highlighted *****

1. Blue Heaven (Diane Ladd,  a young Kurt Russell)
2. Crooked Mile (George Kennedy, Katherine Ross, Royal Dano) *****
3. Old Man (Ned Glass, Robert Hogan, Ed Peck)
4. The Violators (revengeful Denver Pyle, Michael Pate) *****
5. Doctor's Wife (James Broderick, conniving Phyllis Love) *****
6. Take Her, She's Cheap (naive Lauri Peters, Harry Dean Stanton) *****
7. Help Me Kitty (mean desperado Jack Elam) *****
8. Hung High (Ed Asner, Robert Culp, George Lindsay, Elisha Cook) *****
9. Jonah Hutchison (ornery Robert F Simon, Richard Anderson)
10. Big Man, Big Target (Mariette Hartley, J D Cannon)
11. Chicken (Glenn Corbett, L Q Jones, Gigi Perreau) *****
12. Innocence (Claude Akins, Bethel Leslie) *****
13. Aunt Thede (Jeanette Nolan) YAWN, skip this one, for Festus fans only
14. Hammerhead (Arch Johnson, John Fielder, Linda Foster)
15. Double Entry (nefarious Forrest Tucker)
16. Run Sheep Run (Burt Brinckenhoff, Ted Knight, Peter Whitney) *****
17. Deputy Festus (Denver Pyle, Royal Dano) YAWN, Festus fights drunks
18. One Killer On Ice (John Drew Barrymore, Dennis Hopper, Anne Helm) *****

19. Chief Joseph (Robert Loggia, Victor Jory, Willard Sage) *****
20. Circus Trick (Warren Oates, Elizabeth MacRae, Walter Burke)
21. Song For Dying (Theodore Bikel, Lee Majors, Robert F Simon)
22. Winner Take All (Tom Simcox, Margaret Bly, John Milford) *****
23. Eliah's Aim (Jim Hampton) YAWN Festus' cousin wants to shoot off his earlobe
24. Thursday's Child (Jean Arthur, Scott Marlowe)
25. Breckinridge (Ben Cooper, Robert Sorrels)
26. Bank Baby (Jacques Aubochon, Gail Kobe) *****
27. The Lady (Katherine Ross, Eileen Hekart, R G Armstrong) *****
28. Dry Road To Nowhere (James Whitmore, John Saxon. Julie Sommars)
29. Twenty Miles From Dodge (Darren McGavin, Everett Sloan, Aneta Corsaut)
30. The Pariah (John Dehner, Lee Van Cleef)
31. Gilt Guilt (Jan Clayton, Andrew Duggan)
32. Bad Lady From Brookline (Claude Akins, Betty Hutton) AARGH! What The Heck!
33. He Who Steals (Russ Tamblyn, Harold J Stone)
34. Honey Pot (Rory Calhoun, Joanna Moore) *****
35. The Tall Men (George Lindsay, Harry Townes)
36. The New Society (Jeremy Slate, James Gregory, Jack Weston)

THIS IS THE BEST TV SHOW OF ALL TIME. Top notch stories, as good as in any other previous season, and why not, it's the same group of writers (mainly John Meston, Kathleen Hite, Les Crutchfield). Marshall Dillon is as tough and compassionate as he ever was. In fact, some of the episodes are so good, so powerful, that you may not even notice the absence of Chester. On the other hand, there were more than enough episodes about Festus and his kinfolk, felt more like Beverly Hillibillies than Gunsmoke at times. This was sure worth waiting for, seeing all these all time great actors again.

All you angry people out, I'm with you, I love the Gunsmoke series but I'm not paying these prices. Its a complete rip off. I didn't like when they started splitting the seasons in two, so they can double there profits!  Now its worst then that.  There is a solution to this problem, Just wait until the prices come way down. $35.00 a season is more then enough to pay.

Gunsmoke provides western-lovers with a family-friendly great show that emphasizes character, law & order, and good plain common sense. This half-season, as well as all previous episodes, provide a breath of fresh air in an age when many of the most entertaining movies have drifted from such character-building values.  It is amazing to me that the writers were successful in making the plot and storyline consistently excellent and among the best of the classic Westerns from season to season for so many consecutive seasons.  I cannot think of one episode to date that felt weak or that let me down.

Definitely a great addition for the video library of anyone who likes the Western genre, or who likes solid character and good role models in the primary characters, and a strengthening of the ideas of justice, fair play, the rule of law, and even compassion and wisdom throughout.

There is a problem with the liner notes, disc labels and disc menus on disc 4 & 5 in volume 2.  They don't match the programing.  The programs are actually on the discs in the correct order, however the liner notes and the disc labels and the disc menus are wrong.  If you select to watch "He Who Steals" on disc 4, you will actually see "Two Tall Men".  When you select to watch "Two Tall Men" of disc 5, you will see "The New Society" and if you select to watch "The New Society on disc 5, you will see "He Who Steals".  That being said, it was a great show and it is still a great show.  Hopefully, my dad will live to see the next 10 seasons released, but at the rate they are going, that is doubtful.

If you are a fan of the Western genre, this is an absolute must. Great cast, and great guest stars along with fantastic storylines explains just why Gunsmoke lasted for 20 seasons! Originally cast for the role of US Marshall Matt Dillon, John Wayne thankfully turned it down letting us have the 6'7 James Arness of Minnesota fill the role of Matt Dillon, and now, I couldn't see anyone else play that role. Amanda Blake, Milburn Stone, Ken Curtis and Burt Reynolds do wonderfully in this timeless series-you have to see it!
I grew up on this series, never gets old
